docs.lead_paragraph: For all the talk about 25-year-olds making their first (or second) million dollars, the nation's work force is becoming older. Today, 13 percent of workers are at least 55, and that number is expected to rise to 20 percent by 2015. A survey conducted for AARP found that two-thirds of over-45 workers plan to do some work in their retirement years -- but two-thirds also said age discrimination was a fact of life in the workplace.
docs.abstract: Percentage of US workers 55 and older, now 13 percent, is expected to rise to 20 percent by 2015 (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: In a city where dogs command their own shrinks and fashion designers, perhaps pet ambulances were inevitable. With names like Pet Taxi, Pet Chauffeur and Paw Mobile, these companies offer to take your ailing pet to an animal hospital, sometimes on a pint-size stretcher complete with oxygen mask. But unless the dog has a generous health insurance policy, the costs can be steep.

headline.main: The Howl of These Ambulances Is From the Inside
headline.kicker: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE

docs.abstract: Pet advocates, while praising some companies, call for regulation of new pet ambulance service industry in New York City; some clients say companies are charging exorbitant prices and not providing advertised services; Taxi and Limousine Commission says service does not fall under its jurisdiction; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: I was the therapist for a woman with the symptoms and modus operandi that the patient in Lisa Sanders's article had (Sept. 8). She moved all over the United States claiming to be a college student, starting a new job or avoiding a boyfriend. I finally confronted her with the diagnosis of Munchausen. Her mother was also Munchausen and had a history of Munchausen by proxy. I shudder at the costs to her insurance company and the costs to professionals for the energy and time spent with this woman. I could not send her name or description to physicians or hospitals because of confidentiality. Beth L. Roe College Station, Tex.
docs.abstract: Therapist Beth L Roe letter on Lisa Sanders's September 8 article notes confidentiality prevented her from sending name of Munchausen's Syndrome patient to physicians or hospitals around country
